#Text=Alexander Munro of Bearcrofts
#Text=Sir Alexander Munro of Bearcrofts ( died 4 January 1704 ) was a Scottish soldier and politician of the 17th century .
#Text=Lineage
#Text=The Munro of Milntown family descends from John Munro , 1st of Milntown , the second son of Hugh Munro , 9th Baron of Foulis ( d. 1425 ) .
#Text=Three generations after John Munro , 1st of Milntown , is George Munro , 4th of Milntown , who became one of the most prominent ministers in the Reformed Church in the north of Scotland .
#Text=His third son , also called George , 1st of Pitlunde , followed in his footsteps .
#Text=This George 's second eldest son was Alexander Munro , 1st of Bearcrofts . [ 1 ]
#Text=Career
#Text=Alexander took up the army as his profession and served for some time as a Major in an infantry regiment in Ireland .
#Text=He was knighted for his distinguished services in the army and was appointed Commissioner of Stirling . [ 1 ]
#Text=Alexander fought for King Charles II at the Battle of Worcester ( 3 September 1651 ) .
#Text=He survived the battle and was not captured , afterward he took to the study of the law . [ 2 ]
#Text=In 1657 he bought a small Stirlingshire property called Bearcrofts , which lies on the flat southern shore of the Firth of Forth near Grangemouth .

#Text=In 1660 he was appointed Commissary of Stirlingshire , that is to say , judge of the local court , representing the old ecclesiastical court , with jurisdiction in questions of marriage , divorce , affiliation and testaments .
#Text=Two years later he passed advocate of the Scottish bar , and in 1669 he was nominated one of the six clerks in the Court of Session , the supreme court in Scotland .

#Text=In June 1676 , when the staff of clerks was reduced to three , he lost his place and , attributing this result to the machinations of the Duke of Lauderdale , he joined the malcontent Presbyterian party . [ 2 ]

#Text=In the spring of 1683 he and several sympathisers went to London , ostensibly to arrange for a Scots colony in the Carolinas , but really to help the Earl of Shaftesbury in a great Whig plot to overthrow the King and Government and to exclude the Catholic Duke of York from succession to the throne .

#Text=An inner circle of conspirators , including nine of the Scotsmen except Robert Ferguson , had a scheme to waylay and murder the King and the Duke of York at the Rye House while on their way from Newmarket to London .
#Text=In June 1683 the Government discovered both plots , and Commissary Munro , among many others , was arrested .
#Text=After a Preliminary examination by the Privy Council he and a dozen other Scotsmen were sent to Edinburgh for trial and ware imprisoned in the Tolbooth in solitary confinement for ten months .
#Text=The authorities raised prosecutions against 23 conspirators , all but three being fugitives , and in order to get evidence they decided to apply torture to some of the prisoners .
#Text=Munro was threatened with the " boots " ( an instrument of torture involving the crushing of limbs ) and confessed evidence which was used at several of the trials .
#Text=His weakness " did so discompose and confound him , to discover others , that he desperately offered money to the keeper of the Tolbuith 's man to run him throw ( sic ) with his sword . "
#Text=He was then pardoned and liberated , but remained in obscurity till the Revolution of 1688 .
#Text=In 1690 he entered the Scottish Parliament as the shire commissioner for Stirlingshire and at first joined the " Club " , the organized opposition to the Court party .
#Text=He afterwards supported the Government and in 1695 was knighted and granted a pension of £150 per annum as a recompense for his sufferings .
#Text=He died on 4 January 1704 , leaving three daughters and two sons . [ 3 ]
#Text=Family
#Text=Alexander 's wife was Lillias , daughter of John Eastoun of Couston in Linlithgowshire .
#Text=Their sons were :
#Text=George Munro , 1st of Auchinbowie , a successful Scottish soldier .
#Text=John Munro , 2nd of Bearcrofts , a surgeon and professor at the University of Edinburgh
#Text=( They also had three daughters ) .
